main.subtitle: Your guide to the rulings of Sujood As-Sahw in prayer.

questions.decrease_desc: A Rukn (pillar) is an essential part of the prayer, invalid without it (e.g., bowing, prostrating). A Wajib (obligation) is something that invalidates the prayer if left intentionally, but not if forgotten (e.g., the first Tashahhud).

increase.title: Ruling in Case of Addition
increase.details:
If you mistakenly add a bow, prostration, or a full rak'ah to your prayer, your prayer is still valid.

  • Complete your prayer until the Tasleem.
  • After the Tasleem, perform two prostrations for forgetfulness.
  • Then, make the Tasleem again.
increase.daleel: The hadith of Abdullah ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (ﷺ) prayed Dhuhr with five rak'ahs. When asked, "Has the prayer been increased?" He said, "What is that?" They said, "You prayed five." So he performed two prostrations after he had made the Tasleem. (Agreed upon).

decrease_wajib.title: Ruling in Case of Omitting an Obligation (Wajib)
decrease_wajib.details:
If you forget an obligation (like the first Tashahhud) and remember it after moving to the next pillar, do not go back.

  • Continue your prayer as normal.
  • Before making the final Tasleem, perform two prostrations for forgetfulness.
  • Then, make the Tasleem.
decrease_wajib.daleel: The hadith of Abdullah ibn Buhaynah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (ﷺ) stood up after two rak'ahs in Dhuhr without sitting. When he finished his prayer... he performed two prostrations before the Tasleem, then made the Tasleem. (Agreed upon).

decrease_rukn.title: Ruling in Case of Omitting a Pillar (Rukn)
decrease_rukn.details:
Omitting a pillar is a serious mistake and is not fixed by the two prostrations alone.

You must perform the pillar you missed and what comes after it. If you don't, your prayer is invalid.

  • If you remember before reaching its place in the next rak'ah, you must immediately return to perform it and what follows.
  • If you remember after reaching its place in the next rak'ah, the rak'ah in which you missed the pillar is nullified, and the current rak'ah takes its place.
  • In both cases, you complete your prayer and then perform two prostrations for forgetfulness before the Tasleem.
decrease_rukn.daleel: A general principle in Fiqh: "A pillar is not waived due to forgetfulness, nor is it compensated for by Sujood As-Sahw." This is supported by the hadith of the "man who prayed badly," whom the Prophet (ﷺ) commanded to repeat the prayer for omitting a pillar (tranquility), and did not just tell him to perform Sujood As-Sahw.

doubt_prevail.title: Ruling in Case of Doubt with Stronger Inclination
doubt_prevail.details:
If you are in doubt about the number of rak'ahs but have a stronger feeling towards one number.

  • Act upon what you are more certain of and complete your prayer.
  • After making the final Tasleem, perform two prostrations for forgetfulness.
  • Then, make the Tasleem again.
doubt_prevail.daleel: The hadith of Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (ﷺ) said: "If any of you is in doubt during his prayer, he should aim for what is correct, complete his prayer upon it, then make the Tasleem, and then perform two prostrations." (Agreed upon).

doubt_no_prevail.title: Ruling in Case of Doubt without Stronger Inclination
doubt_no_prevail.details:
If you are in doubt about the number of rak'ahs and are not more certain of either choice.

  • Act upon certainty, which is the lesser number (e.g., if in doubt between three and four, assume it is three).
  • Complete your prayer based on that.
  • Before making the final Tasleem, perform two prostrations for forgetfulness.
  • Then, make the Tasleem.
doubt_no_prevail.daleel: The hadith of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "If any of you is in doubt in his prayer and does not know how many he has prayed, three or four, he should cast aside the doubt and build on what is certain, then perform two prostrations before the Tasleem...". (Narrated by Muslim).
